title: 104_hr851
content: The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" is established to create a project for rural telemedicine. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes up to 10 pilot projects to investigate the use of rural health care provider telemedicine networks for physician consultative services under Medicare in rural areas. A rural health care provider telemedicine network includes providers in rural areas collaborating with a multispecialty tertiary care provider for patient referral, joint communications, and transportation. The Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995 establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks in designated rural areas, focusing on joint communications systems and transportation services among network members. The areas of operation are rural health professional shortage areas or underserved rural areas as specified by the Secretary. The Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995 establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks in designated rural areas, focusing on joint communications systems and transportation services among network members. Medicare payment for participants is addressed in Section 3 of the Act. The Act establishes projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks, allowing payments for physician consultations with medicare beneficiaries in rural areas, even if not in the same location. The Secretary will determine payment amounts based on available funds and include costs for signal transmission facilities. Payments may also be made for nonphysician providers. Payments may be made for nonphysician providers for services using signal transmission facilities for physician consultative services. SEC. 4. ELIGIBILITY OF NETWORKS. A network can participate in a pilot project if it meets certain requirements set by the Secretary. The term "rural area" is defined in the Social Security Act. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS. The Secretary will prioritize networks that facilitate consultations between patients and specialists through detailed data transmission. Existing networks can also participate in the pilot projects. The Secretary must submit an interim report to Congress within 24 months of making payments for pilot project services, detailing participating projects and networks, expenses, and patient numbers. A final report is due within 1 year after project termination, analyzing cost-effectiveness, impact on patient care quality and access, and providing recommendations for changes in the Medicare program related to telemedicine. The Secretary must submit reports to Congress detailing pilot project expenses, patient numbers, cost-effectiveness, and impact on patient care quality. The reports also provide recommendations for changes in the Medicare program related to telemedicine. Authorization of appropriations from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for a total of $51,000,000 for a demonstration project under this Act, with up to $1,000,000 allocated for administrative purposes, including report submissions.
